awd_titl_txt: NSFDEB-NERC:  The evolutionary genomics of a major transition in evolution
awd_abstract_narration:
Today's life forms are the accumulated result of billions of years of evolution. Biologists recognize several major transitions in evolution that resulted from smaller, simpler units (e.g., single cells) getting together to form larger, more complex forms (e.g., organisms). It is not known whether major transitions occur gradually or very quickly. The researchers will test this fundamental question, using the latest genetic tools applied to the major transition from solitary social living in bees and wasps. By comparing entire genomes (all of the DNA) of species that show solitary, weakly social, and highly social forms, the research asks whether major transitions are the result of small, gradual changes  or rapid changes in the genome. The outcomes are therefore of a fundamental nature, generating basic information on the building blocks of the natural world. The project will also include involvement of underrepresented minority trainees, as well as a substantial educational components, with the aim of inspiring and engaging the public in an understanding of evolution. This will be accomplished through educational websites, videos, outreach presentations and lectures, as well as participation in educational programs organized by the researchers.

To determine whether the major transition from solitary life to societies in insects evolved via gradual or punctuated processes, a collaborative team of US and UK researchers will generate comparable full genome datasets (high quality genomes including chromosomal maps) on multiple species of bees and wasps. They will then apply rigorous bioinformatic analyses on the consolidated datasets to test specific predictions made by the two contrasting hypotheses (gradual versus punctuated). Beyond the evolution of societies, a broader question is whether the same patterns and processes underpin other major evolutionary transitions. To test the predictions in other major transitions (e.g., the transition from single to multi-cellularity, or asexuality to sexuality) the researchers will draw together a community of theoreticians and empiricists with a united expertise in the theory of major transitions and the empirical nature of major transitions in order to evaluate the extent to which there may be common patterns or processes across major transitions. Synthesizing this information, they will develop a cross-disciplinary roadmap for determining the extent to which all major transitions evolved via common evolutionary routes, allowing them to evaluate the generality of evolutionary processes in the complexity of life.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to investigate the evolutionary process behind superorganismality in insects. A superorganism is defined as a collection of organisms that can only survive and reproduce as a collective.  The evolution of superorganisms is considered as one of the major transitions in the evolutionary history of life, yet how superorganisms evolve is still a mystery.

 

This research sought to use comparisons of genetic information across species to understand how superorganismality evolves. To do this, the team used the bee and wasp tree of life to carefully choose a highly informative set of 17 bee and wasp species with different forms of behavior, from solitary to weakly social to superorganismal.  They then used state-of-the art sequencing technology to generate large volumes of data of two types-- 1) very high resolution maps of the entire genome (all the DNA information) and 2) social behavior transcriptomes (RNA-based gene activity in insects with different social roles).

 

Despite the challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic, the project successfully procured bee and wasp samples from around the world, spanning different levels of sociality, from solitary to weakly social, to superorganismal. Working with Cantata Bio, the team generated high-quality genome assemblies for 17 bee and wasp species, including near chromosome-level assemblies for most. Additionally, RNA-sequencing data was obtained from a subset of species. Because of this coordinated effort, data for all species are highly comparable and we set benchmarks to ensure extremely high quality and completeness. We first conducted a smaller-scale study with the RNA data from 6 species, and utilized novel gene network analysis and support vector machine learning analysis methods.  We identified conserved gene expression patterns across species, allowing us to uncover a core “genetic toolkit” of just over 100 genes with high relevance to sociality. Then, we utilized the power of our extremely high quality (chromosome level) genomes for the first ever analysis of genome structural evolution and its relationship to sociality.  Results indicate high levels of genome rearrangements in bees and wasps, with hot spots in areas containing genes related to chemical perception (e.g. olfaction, or “smell”).  This suggests the evolution of superorganisms was enabled by evolutionary changes at the level of genomes that facilitated more complex forms of chemical communication.

 

In addition, the project team organized and participated in symposia and conferences focused on the evolution of sociality and major transitions. These events facilitated discussions about general patterns and mechanisms common to social evolution across various animal groups, providing a platform for the dissemination of project ideas and findings. The project resulted in a perspective piece published in Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London, outlining a framework for using genomic data to test hypotheses about major transitions. This publication presented suggestions to the broader research community on how such a framework could be applied to various evolutionary transitions. A mini-review paper was also published, discussing the evolution of division of labor in social insects involves the repeated evolution of genetic and genomic pathways associated with nutritional regulation.

 

Opportunities for Training and Professional Development: The project offered significant professional development opportunities, particularly for junior scientists. Two postdoctoral researchers, Dr. Katie Geist and Dr. Emeline Favreau, were directly supported by the NSF funds. They presented their research at conferences, received bioinformatics training, and contributed to publications. Several undergraduate students were involved, and a high school teacher, Jacob Hall, conducted independent research and developed teaching modules. This project fostered mentorship and research opportunities for emerging scientists.

 

Dissemination of Results: The project results were shared through various conference presentations, talks, and symposia organized by the project team. Findings were disseminated at public seminars, outreach events, international conferences and through publications in scientific journals. Genetic data are ready for sharing in public repositories upon final publication. 

 

Broader Impacts: The project has had a broader impact by advancing our understanding of how complex biological systems evolve, using the transition to superorganismality in insects as a focal point. The research provides valuable insights into the genetic and genomic underpinnings of social behavior in bees and wasps, which may have broader implications for understanding the evolution of sociality in other species. The collaborative nature of the project has drawn together theoreticians and empiricists, facilitating cross-disciplinary discussions and enhancing the broader impact of the research.

 

Intellectual Merit: The project has demonstrated intellectual merit by addressing a fundamental question in evolutionary biology. By conducting extensive genomic and transcriptomic analyses, the research has provided evidence and insights into whether the major transition to superorganismality occurred through gradual or punctuated processes. The use of advanced bioinformatic methods and the generation of high-quality genomic data contribute to the intellectual depth of the project. Furthermore, the development of a cross-disciplinary roadmap for evaluating the generality of evolutionary processes in the complexity of life underscores the project's intellectual significance.
